subject: Education
subcategory: The Science of Memory and Study
title: The Testing Effect: Why Quizzes Beat Re-Reading
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on The Testing Effect: Why Quizzes Beat Re-Reading.

hook.text: Students who quiz themselves remember 50% more one week later than students who re-read the same material three times.

buildup.text: The testing effect: the act of retrieving information from memory strengthens the memory more than re-exposure does.

discovery.text: Even failed retrieval attempts help. Trying to remember and getting it wrong improves later learning of the correct

twist.text: Students overwhelmingly prefer re-reading over self-testing. The strategy that feels best produces the worst results.

climax.text: Testing isn't just assessment â€” it's the most powerful learning strategy ever validated. Every quiz is a learning

punchline.text: The best way to study for a test is to take a test. Before the test.

quiz.question: Why is self-testing more effective than re-reading?
